job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician III in Charleston, WV
pros:
Pay can be decent depending on position

Most workers are friendly

Definitely won't get bored at work, they're a very busy hospital
cons:
You don't get sick days. If you're a contract worker (which a lot of the managers seem to be) you do, but if you work just for CAMC you do not. If you get sick it counts as an "occasion" unless you show up for work on time and stay for half of your shift. You may get 3 occasions in 6 months, if you get a 4th occasion in 6 months you can get fired on the spot. Doesn't matter if you have doctors notes, doesn't matter if you were in one of CAMC's own ERs, you will get an occasion. If your boss/employee health will let you take a couple days off it will come out of any PTO you may have saved up, if you have no PTO to use you won't be paid while sick. I understand the reasoning, but when you work with the public, especially in a hospital, you'd think they'd want legitimately sick people to stay home. So, everyone works sick, gets everyone else in the department sick and the cycle repeats every few weeks. And no, I didn't get fired for sick days, I almost never took a sick day, but the whole process is flawed and they make you feel like you're a little kid holding a thermometer to a lightbulb to get out of school even when you're literally in their ER with an IV drip.

Their interdepartmental communication is terrible

The buildings are falling apart

They have a lot of shady practices when it comes to billing patients. Fairly common practice for the billing department to say they'll work out payments with low-income patients only to turn them over to a collections agency instead

Side note-y, but is a perfect example of upper management's general behavior, I recently found out the health insurance company they use (Bluecross Blueshield) is involved in a lawsuit for making "secret deals" with other insurance companies to keep premiums high. I asked a couple of my former co-workers if CAMC had told them about the lawsuit that's going on, big surprise, CAMC hadn't informed anyone there about the problem with their insurance company.

review_title: Its not great, but not all bad, I guess
pros: Decent training, they keep you certified and provide regular training.  My unit was some what new, it was kept well stocked and the equipment was in good working order.  I was put on nights but I regularly got 5-7 days off in a row (I had to work 5 or 6 in a row to get that)
cons:
They are cheap, penny pinchers.  They give you 4 hours over time, then turn right around and send you home 4 hours early tommorrow to eliminate your OT.  I think the managers get bonused on eliminating overtime so they prevent you from having it at all costs.  Yet they will hire 5 travelers and pay them 45-55 an hour all day long.  My unit was 50% travelers probably.  
They used shift differentials as an incentive to work nights.  Most new employees start on nights.  So you basically make 5 more dollars to work nights, but its screwed up necause it can take a couple years to get the senority for a day shift spot, but you end up going back to new hire salary because the shift differial is gone.

pros: Busy job, CEO and his associates appreciate employees.  Parking is somewhat provided for employees in that employees and visitors share areas.  There is opportunity to meet people.  Co-workers are friendly and very helpful.
cons: Low pay; pay increases are annual and only pennies on the dollar; it can take more than 2 years to get a $1.00 raise.  Annual reviews are intentionally degrading to keep the raises small.  Employees are below poverty level.  There's a lot of work, requiring the use of micro soft office suite programs; there are about 8 committees that this position has to do the minutes for and distribute. Insurance benefits are terminated within 7 days of leaving, even though you have not received last pay check.  This company is not required to provide last pay check upon termination, but do so on the next pay date.
